AttackerCapabilities: Ability to manipulate files on the target system
Knowledge of PHP shell upload and execution

Vulnerabilities: Incorrect password check in WordPress user authentication

Steps.Description: Exploit the ability to flip a random bit in the WordPress installation.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: By flipping a bit in the WordPress installation, the attacker can potentially manipulate the behavior of the application.
StepDetails.Action: Flip the comparison check in /var/www/html/wp-includes/user.php at position 5389 to always allow login even with an incorrect password.
StepDetails.Result: The attacker successfully modifies the comparison check to bypass the correct password requirement.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: By bypassing the password check, the attacker can log in as an admin user.
StepDetails.Action: Attempt to log in with any username and an incorrect password.
StepDetails.Result: The login is successful, granting the attacker admin privileges.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: By uploading a PHP shell, the attacker can gain remote code execution on the target system.
StepDetails.Action: Exploit the insecure file upload functionality in the WordPress application to upload a PHP shell.
StepDetails.Result: The PHP shell is successfully uploaded to the target system.

StepDetails.Hypothesis: By executing the PHP shell, the attacker can interact with the target system and read the flag.
StepDetails.Action: Access the uploaded PHP shell and execute commands to read the flag.
StepDetails.Result: The flag is successfully read by the attacker.
